prj.intro: A short selection of some interesting projects I have been involved in professionally and some private projects that are available on GitHub

qv.title: Astronomical Observations Queue Visualization
p0: The Gemini Observatory's two 8.1-meter telescopes located in Hawai'i and Chile are amongst
the most powerful telescopes for research in astronomy in the world. Observation time is in
high demand and great effort is put into optimizing the planning and execution of observations.
p1: The optimal execution time for observations that get selected for execution during a semester
depends on many parameters like the visibility and altitude of the target in the sky, weather
conditions, additional time constraints, sky brightness given by the moon phase, availability
of instruments and specific instrument configurations and many more.
p2: Gemini's Queue Visualization Tool (QV) supports the planning team in the long- and mid-term
scheduling of observations by providing a wide variety of filter options to select subsets of
all observations in the observations database and then sort them by some parameters (e.g.
priority, remaining execution time) and visualize the visibility and altitude above horizon
p3: In addition to filter, grouping and sorting functionality QV also allows to turn on or off several
constraints like instrument availability or minimum elevation and sky brightness to allow for a
'what-if' analysis to easily check the feasibility or the impact of different scenarios.
p4: While originally planned for a handful of specific use cases, the final application turned out to be
flexible enough to cover a wide variety of useful 'query' operations on the database and is now used in
contexts outside of mid- and long-term queue planning, too.

ltts.title: Clearance Support for High Powered Laser Usage in Astronomy
p0Html: Astronomical observatories often use high powered lasers to project artificial 'guide stars' (i.e.
points of light) on high atmospheric layers. These are used as a reference in
Adaptive Optics systems
in order to correct for atmospheric turbulences. Although highly unlikely, the use of such lasers could
interfere with the operation of satellites in space and has therefore to be cleared
by the US military.
p1: Aim of this project was to replace a labor intense manual process with an automated one. Furthermore it
should also improve the support for the telsecope operators during the night. The new process automatically
collects for each night with laser operations potential observation targets from the
observatory's observations database depending on their visibility and other criterias and compiles
a target list. This list is uploaded to a dedicated web site run by the military. Once the target list has
been processed and clearance windows have been calculated, the system is notified by email and will then download the clearance list which defines
for each target of that night at which times down to the second it is allowed to propagate the laser.
p2: To make sure these clearance windows are adhered to, the application is constantly monitoring the
current telescope pointing position and comparing it with those windows. If it detects that the laser
is used outside a window that has been cleared by the military the laser is automatically shuttered.
p3: A web frontend allows to see the current state of the system and gives visual and audible clues when
during long during observations a closure window is approaching and the laser needs to be shuttered.

nets.title: Network-wide Track Management System for Swiss Federal Railways
p0Html: The Swiss Federal Railways (SBB) operate one of the densest railway networks in the world. In order
to replace an existing planning software with a more modern solution with improved functionality a team
of 25 developers and UI specialists from SBB and external companies was tasked during two years with a
complete rewrite based on an Eclipse RCP
client and a server based on WebSphere and an
Oracle database.
p1: I was responsible to orchestrate the development effort of the 5 head strong Business Layer Team and also
actively involved in the development, planning decisions and some architectural decisions. Main focus of
the Business Layer Team was to provide services like for example detailed information about rolling stock
and train compositions or railway network information including detailed track information down to traffic
lights and signalisation. Other aspects covered by those services are the daily train schedules,
journey time calculations based on actual train parameters like engines and weight and checks which can
be used to validate if planned schedules are feasible.
p2: After an earlier attempt to replace the existing software had failed because of the complexity of this
project, SBB wanted to try an agile development process. Great care was also taken to involve a group
of end users in the development process. This continuous user feedback on the current state of the
software proved invaluable to verify the requirements and to detect and address usability and performance
p3Html: on the web page of another external company that was involved in the project.
